title-group.article-title: Effect of partial substitution of aluminum hydroxide with colemanite in fire retarded low-density polyethylene

contrib-group.aff: Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Cevdet Kaynak, Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara TR-06531, Turkey. Email: ckaynak@metu.edu.tr

abstract.p: Metal hydroxides have long been considered as abundant and low-cost fillers for the development of halogen-free flame-retarded polyolefins. However, large filler loading levels are required in the matrix resin to achieve satisfactory fire retardant performance, which results in deteriorated processing characteristics and poor mechanical properties of compounds. Therefore, this study was aimed at improving the fire retardancy of low-density polyethylene and decreasing the total filler loading in the resin using combinations of aluminum hydroxide and a natural hydrated calcium borate, namely, colemanite mineral. Flame retardancy was studied by the mass loss calorimeter analysis, limiting oxygen index measurements, and UL94 classification. Peak heat release rate and total heat evolved were lowered by around 20% and 15%, respectively, with partial replacement of aluminum hydroxide by colemanite, which facilitated the use of lower total filler loading in the resin. Depending on colemanite content and total filler loading, limiting oxygen index was increased by 1%–4% while maintaining the UL94 V-0 rating. Fire retardant effect of colemanite used in conjunction with aluminum hydroxide was attributed to better protective character of fire residues and more effective fuel trapping in the condensed phase. Lower elastic modulus and higher ductility was obtained due to decreased total filler loading in the matrix.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the increased consumption of plastics for applications in automotive, aerospace, electrical/electronics, building, and cable industries, a wide variety of additive type flame retardants were developed over the past years. Among those additives, halogenated flame retardants are currently being forced by environmental requirements to be replaced by halogen-free counterparts, a typical and widely used example of which is aluminum hydroxide (ATH). It is generally accepted that ATH functions as a flame retardant owing to its endothermic dehydration reaction acting as a heat sink cooling the fuel in the condensed phase. In addition, water of dehydration evolves into the flaming zone effectively cooling/diluting the available fuel in the gas phase. Moreover, porous ceramic residues forming as the dehydration product, that is, γ-aluminum oxide in the case of ATH, provide heat insulation by forming an inert protective barrier layer on exposed sample surface during combustion. A recent article by Hull et al.1 extensively reviews the modes of action of endothermically decomposing mineral fillers.

The primary concern with the use of halogen-free additives, especially with metal hydroxides, is that large filler loadings are required to attain satisfactory flame retardancy, which in turn causes deteriorated mechanical properties and processing issues. Therefore, much of the recent research on the development of halogen-free flame-retarded resins has focused on the use of combinations of additives to decrease total additive loading by improving the fire retardant effectiveness of hydrated mineral fillers. In previous studies, combinations of hydrated mineral fillers with melamine and its salts,2–4 red phosphorus,5–9 magnesium hydroxide,10,11 huntite and hydromagnesite,12,13 and expandable graphite5,14,15 were considered. The reader is referred to a comprehensive review by Weil and Levchik16 on this matter.

Among boron based additives, zinc borates have extensively been used in conjunction with aluminum and magnesium hydroxides,17–24 while other boron-containing substances such as boron–silicon containing preceramic oligomers, boron phosphate, ammonium pentaborate, and calcium borates have only rarely been considered as synergistic fire retardants.25–30 The colemanite (CMT) mineral, a natural hydrated calcium borate with formula 2CaO·3B2O3·5H2O, might be an alternative to zinc borate and other hydrated mineral fillers for use in combination with ATH owing to its abundance, low cost, and relatively high dehydration temperature above 300°C. Therefore, this study explores the fire retardancy of CMT when used in conjunction with ATH in low-density polyethylene (LDPE) compounds.

sec.title: Materials, compounding, and shaping
sec.p: LDPE (Argento 15803-020) was used as the matrix material. Fine-precipitated ATH was obtained from Albemarle (Bergheim, Germany) (Martinal OL-107) and had an average particle size in the range of 0.9–1.5 µm. Ground CMT, with a formula 2CaO·3B2O3·5H2O, had an average particle size of 9.3 µm and was kindly provided by ETI Mine Works (Turkey). An anhydride modified polyethylene (Fusabond E226, Du Pont, Geneva, Switzerland) was used at 5 phr as the compatibilizer to promote adhesion between matrix and additives. Table 1 summarizes the details of materials investigated.

caption.p: Designations and compositions (wt%) of studied materials

fn.p: LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: Materials were compounded using a single-screw extruder (Brabender Plasticorder, L/D = 25, Brabender, Duisburg, Germany) by employing a temperature profile of 90°C–125°C–160°C–185°C–200°C at 100 r/min screw speed. After pelletizing, compounds were shaped to the required dimensions using a custom hot press at 130°C platen temperature, under 40 bar pressure.

sec.title: Characterization and testing
sec.p: Combustion was carried out under an external heat flux of 50 kW/m2 on 100 × 100 × 4 mm3 square samples using a mass loss calorimeter with chimney and thermopile attachments (Fire Testing Technology, UK) conforming to ISO 13927 standards. Reference measurements indicated that heat release rates were reproducible to well below ±10%. The mass loss calorimeter tests were performed in duplicate, and average values were reported. Limiting oxygen index (LOI) was determined using an oxygen index apparatus (Fire Testing Technology) conforming to ISO 4589 standards. Additionally, samples with 3.2 mm thickness were classified according to UL94 standards using a flammability meter designed based on the standard apparatus.

Combustion residues were collected and analyzed by means of energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) using a scanning electron microscope (FEI Nova NanoSEM 400, FEI, Eindhoven, The Netherlands) at 20 kV acceleration voltage. Thermal degradation behavior was analyzed on a simultaneous thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) equipment (Netzsch Model STA 449 F3 Jupiter, Netzsch, Selb, Germany) at a heating rate of 10°C/min under flowing nitrogen at 20 mL/min. Tension tests were performed on at least three ISO 527 Type 1A samples for each composition using a universal testing machine (Instron 5565A, 5 kN, Instron, Norwood, MA, USA) at a crosshead speed of 1 mm/min.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 1 contains the results of LOI and UL94 tests of compounds studied as a function of CMT loading and total filler loading. It is clear that LDPE requires high ATH loading of 65 wt% to satisfy the UL94 V-0 criteria. Keeping this large total loading level constant, LOI was improved by 1%–4% with CMT replacement of ATH by maintaining the V-0 classification. At a reduced total filler loading of 60 wt%, CMT replacement provided UL94 V-0 ratings along with satisfactory LOI values above 28%. None of the samples with a total loading level of 55 wt% could satisfy the V-0 criteria despite the improvements in LOI up to 3% with CMT replacement. It can be generalized considering all total loading levels studied that the largest synergistic improvements in LOI were seen when ATH was replaced by CMT at 10 wt% in the resin.

caption.p: Limiting oxygen index and UL94 ratings as a function of CMT content and total filler loading.
ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite; NR: non-rated.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the forced flaming combustion behavior of compounds under an external irradiation corresponding to typical heat flux in developing fires.31 It is seen that lower heat release rates were obtained with an increase in ATH loading and also by replacing a certain amount of ATH with CMT keeping the total filler loading constant. Characteristically, LDPE/ATH compounds without CMT addition (Figure 2(a)) demonstrated clear second peak heat release rate (PHRR) toward the end of combustion where the height of the peak increases with decreasing ATH content. The second peak is thought to arise from the diminishing mass of fuel being subject to more rapid heating toward the end of combustion. It is noteworthy that the second PHRR was significantly suppressed in the presence of CMT, particularly when total filler loading was 55 and 60 wt% in the resin (Figure 2(c) and (d)). The suppression of heat release in the late stages of combustion of LDPE/ATH/CMT compounds might be attributed to more efficient trapping of fuel in the condensed phase in the presence of CMT.

caption.p: Heat release rate curves of compounds obtained under 50 kW/m2 external irradiation.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: Table 2 lists the fire parameters of studied compounds obtained by the mass loss calorimeter analysis. It is clear that the total heat evolved (THE) and PHRR were lowered with CMT addition, though there seems to be no explicit relationship of THE or PHRR reduction with CMT content of compounds. Maximum THE reductions obtained with CMT substitution were around 15% with respect to LDPE/ATH compounds. The decreases in THE suggest that CMT containing residue was able to trap more fuel in the condensed phase as discussed later by residue characterization. Maximum PHRR reductions of 24%, 18%, and 17% were obtained with CMT replacement of ATH at total filler loading levels of 55, 60, and 65 wt%, respectively. Therefore, considering PHRR, it can be stated that enhancement of fire retardancy by CMT addition becomes more pronounced at lower total filler loading. Moreover, comparing the reference compound LDPE/65ATH with compounds containing CMT, it is clear that similar fire retardant performance could be achieved with a lower total filler loading level of 60 wt% in the resin. It should be noted that LDPE/50ATH/10CMT and LDPE/40ATH/20CMT samples showed even lower PHRR than LDPE/65ATH.

caption.p: Combustion characteristics of studied materials under 50 kW/m2 irradiation

fn.p: THE: total heat evolved; PHRR: peak heat release rate; LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: THE to total mass loss (TML) ratio was calculated as a measure of effective heat of combustion (ΔHc,eff) of volatiles averaged over the whole test.31 The ΔHc,eff was decreased with the loading level of ATH due to more fuel dilution in the gas phase by the larger amount of water vapor evolution. However, it was only slightly affected by CMT replacement of ATH due to the fact that lower amount of water released from CMT (as explained below) was balanced by more efficient trapping of fuel in the condensed phase manifesting itself as lower THE. In order to reveal the mechanism of fire retardancy in LDPE/ATH/CMT compounds, samples were analyzed by means of TG/DTA, and fire residues were characterized by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy.

It can be observed by analyzing TG/DTA curves given in Figure 3 that ATH undergoes an endothermic dehydration reaction in the temperature range of 250°C–330°C with ∼35% overall mass loss. On the other hand, CMT decomposes within a significantly higher temperature range of 350°C–440°C with the formation of water molecules from structural hydroxyl groups and breaking of hydrogen bonds between water and borate chains32 leading to the release of water vapor corresponding to ∼20% overall mass loss. Figure 4 shows the thermal degradation behavior of the LDPE compounds with total filler loading of 60 wt%. Due to the lower amount of structural water and higher decomposition temperature of CMT compared to ATH, the onset temperature of decomposition and percent char residue of LDPE compounds were increased with CMT content.

caption.p: (a) Thermogravimetric sample mass and (b) DTA heat flow curves of CMT, ATH, and LDPE matrix under flowing nitrogen.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite; DTA: differential thermal analysis.
Thermogravimetric (a) sample mass and (b) mass loss rate curves of compounds with total filler loading of 60 wt% showing the influence of CMT content.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: It is clear from Table 2 that the amount and thickness of fire residue from LDPE/ATH/CMT compounds were higher compared to LDPE/ATH compounds at the same total filler loading, where the influence of CMT became more pronounced with increasing CMT content. Figure 5 shows the appearance of residues formed by combustion of compounds in the mass loss calorimeter. The alumina residue formed in the absence of CMT is more cohesive and crack free compared to residues formed in the presence of CMT. In the case of CMT substitution, the smooth alumina layer formed earlier during combustion was then disintegrated by the act of pressure buildup and subsequent rapid water release typical for CMT dehydration.28 Although cracks are usually detrimental to the protective function, residues with CMT were more effective in trapping fuel in the condensed phase and hence lowering the THE.

caption.p: Appearance of fire residues from compounds with total filler loading of 60 wt% showing the influence of CMT addition.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: Figure 6 shows a representative cross section of fire residue from LDPE/ATH/CMT compounds. It is clear by analyzing Al/Ca ratio in the residues that the upper parts of the residue, that is, regions close to the exposed surface, were rich in Ca. This would mean that upper part of the residue was enriched with decomposition products of CMT. Such segregation of CMT and its decomposition products might explain the more effective fuel trapping in the condensed phase (lower THE) and better insulation of underlying material against external irradiation and heat feedback from the flame during combustion (lower PHRR). However, the segregation of CMT had an adverse effect by lowering the time to ignition as reported in Table 2. This can be attributed to the fact that CMT, having less endothermic cooling effect compared to ATH, was closer to the exposed surface leading to faster heating of LDPE to the ignition temperature.

caption.p: Distribution of Al and Ca in a representative fire residue from LDPE/ATH/CMT compounds.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.p: Figure 7 shows the influence of total filler loading and CMT addition on the mechanical properties of compounds. Tensile strength and modulus were increased with higher total filler loading, whereas ductility and toughness were reduced. Keeping the total loading level constant, addition of CMT caused slight decreases in tensile strength which might be attributed to larger average particle size of CMT with respect to ATH. However, CMT replacement of ATH improved the ductility and toughness at least to some degree. Comparing the overall mechanical properties of CMT containing compounds with the reference compound LDPE/65ATH, it can be seen that lower elastic modulus and higher ductility were obtained owing to decreased total filler loading while maintaining the fire retardant performance.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of studied compounds as a function of CMT content and total filler loading: (a) tensile strength, (b) elastic modulus, and (c) ductility.
LDPE: low-density polyethylene; ATH: aluminum hydroxide; CMT: colemanite.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study explores the use of CMT, a natural hydrated calcium borate, as a partial replacement for ATH in LDPE. It was found that the extent of PHRR reduction by CMT incorporation increases with decreasing total filler loading in the resin. Keeping the total filler loading constant at 65 wt%, PHRR decreased with increasing CMT content, while lower THE was obtained at all CMT levels. Moreover, CMT-containing compounds demonstrated better fire retardant properties compared to the LDPE/65ATH reference compound at a lower total filler loading of 60 wt%. Keeping the total loading level constant, CMT replacement of ATH improved LOI values by 1%–4% and maintained UL94 V-0 ratings. In particular, the total filler loading level could be decreased to 60 wt% while maintaining the UL94 V-0 rating.

When compared to ATH, CMT was shown to undergo dehydration at a higher temperature, which is accompanied by lower amount of water release. Therefore, CMT-containing compounds showed increased thermal stability in terms of onset temperature of decomposition and percent char residue. Fire retardant mechanism of CMT used in conjunction with ATH is related with the formation of thicker residues providing better barrier effect and more efficient fuel trapping in the condensed phase.

Keeping the total filler loading at a constant level, incorporation of CMT increased ductility and toughness. In particular, compared to LDPE/65ATH reference compound, lower elastic modulus and higher ductility were obtained at a decreased total filler loading while maintaining the fire retardant performance. The materials show potential to be suitable for cable sheathing applications.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge METU Central Laboratory for providing the research facilities.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: National Boron Research Institute of Turkey (BOREN grant no. 2009-C-0236) and ETI Mine Works Turkey provided partial financial support for this study.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Nihat A Isitman was awarded a PhD degree in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering at Middle East Technical University in the year 2012. His research focused on interfaces in short fiber reinforced polymer nanocomposites and flame retardancy of polymers and nanocomposites. He has authored about 20 SCI journal articles during his PhD study. He is currently working as a materials scientist at Goodyear Innovation Center.

Cevdet Kaynak is a full professor at the Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering and Department of Polymer Science and Technology at the Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey. His research interest focuses on the engineering performance of polymer-based nanocomposites. He has authored about 50 journal articles and 60 conference proceedings.
